Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Dennis Kriventsov is "Regularity of Solutions to Elliptic Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, New York University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Fanghua Lin.

Performance_Institution.Name: New York University, Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work funded by this award consisted of several projects at the intersection of elliptic regularity theory, free boundaries, and the calculus of variations.

One strand of research focused on a problem related to thermal insulation. A domain at an elevated temperature is insulated by a material from its cooler environment, and then the exterior of that insulator is painted with a very thin layer of a much stronger insulating material. The goal, then, is to choose the shape of the insulation in such a way as to minimize the heat lost to the exterior, given a fixed amount of material. In work (some joint with Luis Caffarelli) funded by this grant, we studied the existance of minimizing shapes to this problem, as well as the structure of the exterior boundary. We found that the problem has a strong connection to the Mumford-Shah functional in image segmentation, but has rather different local structure.

Another project, joint with Fanghua Lin, dealt with optimizing the k-th eigenvalue of the Laplacian (with homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions) over all domains with a fixed volume. The shape of such minimal domains is poorly understood, and we studied the local structure of the domain using modern free boundary theory. This naturally led us to a new regularity theorem for a class of vector-valued free boundary problems, which classifies the boundary into large smooth pieces, a small (but expected) set of cone-like singularities, and then a poorly understood set of cusps. In ongoing work, we are studying these cusps in more detail, as well as looking at other applications of these vectorial free boundary methods to physical problems, such as liquid crystals.

The research funded by this award was specifically geared towards fostering interaction with several related areas of mathematics (minimal surfaces, shape optimization, stability of functional inequalities), as well as physics and material science. In particular, we hope that the new free boundary techniques developed will help to provide new mathematical approaches to the inherently vector-valued problems arising in elasticity and fluids.
